editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

p.hi: WHat is Catechiลฟing?

sp.speaker: Beniamin.
sp.p: It is a plaine1 Cor. 3.1.2. & 14.19. Nehem 8.8. familiar, and briefe declaring by liuely voyce, of theHeb 5.12. & 6.1. Principles of Chriลฟtian Religion, out of theActs 18.28. & 28.23. 2 Tim. 4.2. Exod. 12 26 & 13.8. Deut. 6.6 &c. 2 Pet. 1 21. Scripture or Word of God.

p.hi: Who was the author of this forme of teaching?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Euen God himลฟelfe.

p.hi: Hath it beene of any long continuance in the Church of God?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Yes ลฟurely, it was diligently vลฟed in the times of theGal 6.6. The originall word is Catechiลฟe. Heb 5 12, 13. & 6.1. 1 Pet. 3.21. Primitiue Church, and in the dayes of the Apoลฟtles themลฟelues: yea, euen theGen. 19, 19. Exod 12 26. Deut. 6, 7, 8. Fathers of the firลฟt world, long before Chriลฟts Incarnation, after this manner inลฟtructed their families, and ลฟuch
as were vnder their tuition, charge, and gouernement.

p.hi: What profit or benefit doth there ariลฟe from this kind of teaching?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: The benefit which may bee reaped hereby, is very great and manifold:1 Pet. 3.15. For firลฟt it will inable vs to giue a ready anลฟwer to any man that ลฟhall aske vs a reaลฟon of our Faith.

Heb. 5.12.Secondly, it will greatly helpe vs to vnderลฟtand, remember, and profit by the Scriptures.Our people, for the moลฟt part, are rude and vncatechiลฟed: and therefore they profit little or nothing by Sermons. A Sermon to ลฟuch perลฟons, is like a great loafe ลฟer before a Childe. M. Perk. in Gal. c. 4 v. 20. 1 Theลฟ 5.21. Heb. 5.14. 1 Iohn 4.1. 1 Cor. 11.29.
Thirdly, to heare the Word of God preached with much more fruit and commoditie to our ลฟoules, then otherwiลฟe we ลฟhould doe.
Fourthly, to try what we heare or reade, and readily to diลฟcerne true Doctrine from that which is falลฟe, and erroneous.

Fiftly, it will much further our due and worthy receiuing the Lords Supper: to the which none ought to be admitted before they bee skilled in the grounds of our holy Faith, neither without ลฟome competent knowledge thereof, can any with comfort be partaker of it,

Sixtly, it is the high and ready way to bring to ลฟound and ลฟetled knowledge; to the which,Heb. 5.11, 12. 2 Tim. 3.7. whoลฟoeuer is vncatechiลฟed in the Principles of Religion, can neuer attaine, but will be euer learning, and euer ignorant.

Laลฟtly,1 Chron. 28.9 Deut. 17, 18. Pro. 22.6. Matth. 22.29. Acts 3.17. Rom 3.11.12. Epheลฟ. 4.17, 18, 19. it is a ลฟoueraigne preลฟeruatiue againลฟt all infection of errour, impietie, and prophaneneลฟลฟe; and a moลฟt effectuall meanes to maintaine the puritie of ลฟound Doctrine.

p.hi: Why ลฟay you, that Catechiลฟing is a declaring of the Principles of Religion, out of the Scripture or Word of God?

p.hi: Which bee the Canonicall Bookes of the Old Teลฟtament?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: They may be diuided into three orders. The firลฟt containes Hiลฟtoricall books, being narrations of things done: which are, Geneลฟis, Exodus, Leuiticus, Numbers, Deuteronomie, the booke of Ioลฟhua, Iudges, Ruth, two bookes of Samuel, two of the Kings, two of the Chronicles, the bookes of Ezra, Nehemiah, Heลฟter, and Iob.

The ลฟecond are Doctrinall bookes, teaching diuine Doctrines and Precepts. Theลฟe are the bookes of the Pลฟalmes, of the Prouerbes, of the Preacher or Eccleลฟiaลฟtes, and the Song of Songs or the Canticles.

The third comprehends Propheticall bookes, foretelling things to come, whereof ลฟome are greater: namely, the Prophecy of Eลฟay, Ieremie, whereunto belongs his Lamentation, Ezekiel and Daniel: Some ลฟmaller, to wit, Hoลฟea, Ioel, Amos, Obadiah, Ionah, Micah, Nahuฬ, Habakkuk, Zephaniah, Haggai, Zechariah, and Malachie; all which were written in the Hebrew tongue.

p.hi:
Which bee the diuine Canonicall
bookes of the New Teลฟtament?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: They are diลฟtinguiลฟhed into thrรฉe rankes or orders. The firลฟt containes Hiลฟtoricall bookes, which are fiue: The Goลฟpell of S. Matthew, Marke, Luke and Iohn; & the Acts of the Apoลฟtles. The ลฟecond is, of Epiลฟtles which are twenty one in number: one to the Romans, two to the Corinthians, one to the Galathians, one to the Epheลฟians, one to the Philippians, one to the Coloลฟลฟians, two to the Theลฟลฟalonians, two to Timothie, one to Titus, one to Philemon, one to the Hebrewes; of Iames one, of Peter two, of Iohn thrรฉe, and of Iude one. The third, one onely Propheticall booke, called the Apocalips or Reuelation of Saint Iohn; which books were penned in the Grรฉeke tongue.

p.hi: Are not Eลฟdras, Tobit, Iudith, and the other bookes, commonly ioyned in one volume with the bookes before mentioned, and interiected betweene Malachy the laลฟt of the ลฟmall Prophets, and the Goลฟpell of Saint Matthew, parts of the Canonicall Scripture and Word of God alลฟo, and of equall authoritie and credit with the reลฟt mentioned?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No ลฟurely, and therefore are not to be alledged for confirmation of any Doctrine, or grounds of our faith, though they may bee profitably read for example of life, and inลฟtruction of manners.

p.hi: What reaลฟons can you render for the proofe of that you ลฟay?

p.hi: What are the properties of theลฟe Scriptures?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: They haue their whole authoritie from God alone the Author of them, and not from the Church.

p.hi: How proue you this?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Pลฟal. 19.7. & 119.1.2.88. Eลฟay 8.20.Firลฟt, becauลฟe the Scriptures are the Teลฟtimonie of God; now that cannot receiue authoritie from men, and therefore neither the Scriptures.

Secondly, becauลฟe the Scriptures are before the Church; for it isEลฟay 2.2. Mat. 28.19. Acts 1 8.9.10. gathered,Iames 1.13. 1 Pet. 1.23. regenerated, andActs 20.32. &c. Epheลฟ. 4.11.12, 13. Pลฟal. 119.9.105. Epheลฟ. 2.20. gouerned by them.
Thirdly, becauลฟe the Church it ลฟelfe doth depend vpon the Scriptures, and borroweth all her authoritie from them, being built vpon the foundation of the Prophets and Apoลฟtles.

Pลฟal. 19.7. & 119.105.130.All points or Articles of faith needefull to bee knowne vnto ลฟaluation,

sp.speaker: B.

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: To teach all truth and ลฟauing Doctrine,2 Tim. 3.16, 17. Rom. 15.4. Pลฟal. 119.23.50 81.92. to inลฟtruct in righteouลฟneลฟลฟe and vertue, to correct all ลฟinne and wickedneลฟลฟe, and to comfort in all diลฟtroลฟลฟes and perplexities.

p.hi: To whom doth the knowledge of the Scriptures appertaine?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Deut. 17.18, 19. Pลฟal. 119.9. 2 Tim. 3.15. Iohn 5.39. Deut. 6, 7, 8. Col. 3.16.To all men, of what age, condition, qualitie, ranke or degrรฉe whatลฟoeuer. Yea, all ลฟorts of men without exception, are bound to get the knowledge thereof.

p.hi: IS there any God?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Pลฟ. 14.1. & 90.2. Eลฟay 41.4.That there is, euer hath bin, and euer ลฟhall bee a God, is a thing ลฟo conลฟpicuouลฟly apparant, that it ought not once to bee called into queลฟtion,

p.hi: You ลฟay true. Howbeit becauลฟe there haue

For it were moลฟt abลฟurd and abลฟonous from reaลฟon, to thinke, that they either came by chance, could create themลฟelues, or were from euerlaลฟting.
Secondly,Iob 38.5, 6, 7, 8, &c. Mat. 6.26. A & s 14.17. the continuall preลฟeruation and moลฟt wiลฟe and powerfull gouernement of the world, and al things created in the ลฟame, doth argue no leลฟลฟe.

Dan. 5.4.23. ลฟtocks and ลฟtones, rather then they would bee thought to haue no god at all.

Fourthly, the fearefull iudgements which are inflicted vpon vngodly men euen the greateลฟt of them,Exod. 14.27, 28 Iudg. 1.4, 5, 6, 7. Dan. 4.31, 32, 33. Gen. 4.14. Dan. 5.5, 6. Mat 27.3, 4, 5. Rom. 2.15. Humane Hiลฟtories abound with examples of this kinde. p.hi: How many Gods be there?

But God is all and euery of theลฟe, therefore it is impoลฟลฟible that there ลฟhould be more then one onely. Beลฟides, many Heathens by light of nature haue ลฟรฉene and acknowledged this truth.

p.hi:
But the Scripture makes mention in many places of three; namely, the Father, the Sonne, and the Holy Ghoลฟt, and affirmes each of them to bee God; it

Firลฟt, inGen 2.7. Zach. 12.1. Exod. 1.5. Acts 7.14.59. reลฟpect of their ลฟoules, in that as God is, ลฟo are they, of a ลฟpirituall, ลฟimple, intelligible, incorporeall,

Pลฟal. 8.5. & 49.20. 1 Cor. 12.23. ลฟtrength, agilitie, impaลฟลฟibilitie, immortalitie, with a princely maieลฟtie, moลฟt incomparable beauty, and in a word, with all perfections that might giue grace or glory to them; the image of God (though properly ลฟeated in their ลฟoules, yet) illuลฟtrating and moลฟt gloriouลฟly ลฟhining in their bodies alลฟo by the effects thereof.

div.head: Of Mans eลฟtate of miลฟery by his fall.

p.hi: DId they continue in this glorious and happy eลฟtate?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No alas, they did not,Gen. 3.1, 2, &c. Pลฟal. 49.20. but ลฟoone loลฟt the ลฟame, and fell away from God that had giuen it them.

p.hi: How came that to paลฟลฟe?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: By their voluntary and wilfull diลฟobedience to the commandement of God,Gen. 3.6. Eccleลฟ. 7.29. in eating of the forbidden fruit of the trรฉe of knowledge of good and euill.

p.hi: By what meanes were they drawne to eate of this fruit, contrary to Gods commandement?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: By the temptation of the Diuell,Gen. 3.2, 3, &c. who by his wily ลฟubtilty beguiled the woman, making her beleeue that it would redound to the great good both of her and her husband to eate thereof; by which perลฟwaลฟion ลฟhe being ouercome, tooke of the fruit, and did eate, and gaue of the ลฟame to her husband, who did eate alลฟo.

p.hi: What was the good which the Diuell bore the woman in hand they ลฟhould gaine by their eating?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Wiลฟedome and Knowledge.Gen. 3.5, 6.

p.hi: What befell them for this tranลฟgreลฟลฟing Gods Commandement?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
They were inลฟtantly ลฟtript ofGen. 3.7.8.10.17, 18, 19. 23, 24 & 2.17. Leuit. 26.14, 15, &c. Deut 20.15, 16 &c. and 27.26 Iob 14 1. Pลฟal 49 laลฟt. Rom. 6 23. Gal 3.10. Tit. 3 3.
that glorious and happy eลฟtate of their creation; and moreouer, made obnoxious to innumerable legions of ลฟorrowes in this life, to death of body, and to the neuer-ending wrath of God in body and ลฟoule, in the life to come.

p.hi: But doe you not thinke that God herein inflicted too great a puniลฟhment vpon them for their ลฟinne?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No vndoubtedly, he did not.

p.hi: Why ลฟo?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Becauลฟe thereby they tranลฟgreลฟลฟed the commandement of him who is an infinite Maieลฟtie, to the breach of whoลฟe leaลฟt Commandement, there can bee no leลฟลฟe due then an infinite weight of vengeance.

Secondly, becauลฟe this was no ลฟmall or petty ลฟinne, as it may ลฟรฉeme to be, if wee looke no further then the baลฟeneลฟลฟe of the externall obiect; but a moลฟt grieuous, horrible and capitall crime, euen in the higheลฟt degrรฉe.

p.note: This ลฟinne may well bee called with the wicked ลฟpirit in the Goลฟpell, Legion, becauลฟe it was a combination of many execrable ลฟinnes together in one. Gen. 2.17.
p.hi: How make you this to appeare?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Firลฟt, becauลฟe it was not one ลฟimple and ลฟingle ลฟinne alone, but a compoลฟition, and as it were, a concourลฟe
and conglobation of many ลฟeuerall, and thoลฟe moลฟt hainous ลฟinnes together.

sp.speaker: I.

p.hi: Which were they?

sp.p: Firลฟt, damnable infidelitie, in that they beleeued not God, menacing death vnto them, if they diลฟobeyed his Commandement.
Secondly, fearefull contempt of the ลฟacred Maieลฟtie of God,Gen. 3, 4, 5, 6.17. in that they giue credit and yรฉeld obedience to the voyce of the Diuell, rather then to his.

Thirdly, deteลฟtable couetouลฟneลฟลฟe,Gen. 3.6. in that not ลฟatisfied with thoลฟe moลฟt excellent and glorious prerogatiues they were indowed withall, they gape after more, and ลฟรฉeke for a higher eลฟtate then God was pleaลฟed to confer vpon them.
Fourthly, Satanicall pride,Gen 3.5. in that they moลฟt inลฟolently aลฟpire to an equalitie with God himลฟelfe.

Fiftly, intollerable ingratitude, in that when God had made them the principall and nobleลฟt of all his creatures, yea,Gen. 3. their ลฟoueraigne Lords and Kings; and further, dignified them
with his owne image; all this is forgotten, vilified, and made of no account with them, vnleลฟลฟe they may be his fellowes and equalles: alลฟo in that they ลฟo ลฟoone let ลฟlip the memory of thoลฟe manifold vnลฟpeakable fauours beลฟtowed vpon them.
Gen. 2.17.Sixtly, ลฟacrilegious theft, in that they put forth their hands to that which is none of theirs, but anothers, and expreลฟลฟely interdicted them.
Gen. 3.6.Seuenthly, itching curioลฟitie, in that they affect greater wiลฟedome, then God had giuen them, and other knowledge then he had reuealed.
Gen. 3.1, 2, 3, &c.Eightly, horrible blaลฟphemie, in that they ลฟubลฟcribe and giue conลฟent to the ลฟaying of Satan, in which he had charged God with lying and enuie.
Gen. 3.6.Ninthly, epicuriลฟh intemperancie, in that they muลฟt nรฉedes gratifie and pleaลฟe their palate, though Heauen it ลฟelfe be incenลฟed and diลฟpleaลฟed for it.

p.hi: What other circumลฟtances are there which may aggrauate this ลฟin of theirs, and euidence the hainouลฟneลฟลฟe of it?

Thirdly,Gen. 1.29. & 2.16, 17. the great reaลฟon they had to kรฉepe it; namely, the innumerable and ineลฟtimable benefits of God towards them, and in particular, his great bounty, in giuing them frรฉe liberty to eate of all other the trรฉes and fruits in the Garden, whereof there were great aboundance, and all moลฟt delectable; this one onely and no more among them all, being excepted and forbidden them.

p.hi: What difference is there betweene the Bread and Wine in this Sacrament, and the Bread and Wine commonly vลฟed in our priuate houลฟes?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: In nature, ลฟubลฟtance or eลฟลฟence none at all, but onely in vลฟe, office, end and application;1 Cor. 10.16. & 11.24, 25. the one, ลฟeruing for the refreลฟhing, comfort and nouriลฟhment of our bodies; the other (to wit, the Bread and Wine in the Sacrament) being conลฟecrated and ลฟet apart, to be ลฟacred ลฟignes, pleadges and diลฟeaลฟes of the Body and Bloud of Chriลฟt, and of the ลฟpirituall refection, comfort and nou โข iลฟhment of our ลฟoules thereby, vnto eternall life.

As Wax being ลฟealed, differs from it ลฟelfe before ลฟealing, and from other
Waxe, &c. and as Gold or Siluer coyned, from that which is not ลฟtamped with the Kings Image: So differs Bread and Wine in this Sacrament, from other Bread and Wine not applyed to this ลฟacred vลฟe.

p.hi: How are the Elements of Bread and Wine ลฟanctified or conลฟecrated to this diuine and holy vลฟe; namely, to bee the Signes, Symboles, &c. of the Body and Bloud of Chriลฟt?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: By rehearลฟing and declaring the Inลฟtitution and Promiลฟe of Chriลฟt;Mat. 26.26.27, &c. 1 Cor. 10.16.11 23, &c. 1 Tim. 4 4, 5. as alลฟo by the prayers, thankeลฟgiuing and whole action of the Miniลฟter and Communicants, according to our Sauiours Inลฟtitution.

p.hi: How long doth the Bread and Wine continue to bee the ลฟignes of the Body and Bloud of Chriลฟt?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Onely during the time of the celebration and adminiลฟtration of this Sacrament, and no longer,1 Cor. 11.24, 25.26. but as ลฟoone as that is finiลฟhed, they become common Bread, and common Wine as other ordinary Bread and Wine are, and as themลฟelues were, before their conลฟecration.

p.hi: Are the Body and Bloud of Chriลฟt locally, ลฟubลฟtantially, corporally or bodily preลฟent in the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No. His Body and Bloud are truly and really preลฟent with the ลฟignes thereof,1 Cor. 11.24, 25 to wit, the Bread and the Wine by Sacramentall Relation, as words ลฟpoken, and the things ลฟignified by them, are preลฟent together: as alลฟo to the Receiuers or Communicants ลฟpirituallyEpheลฟ. 3.17. by faith, and ลฟo are eaten and drunken of euery belรฉeuer: but other preลฟence, eating or drinking then this, there is none to bee held or belรฉeued.

p.hi: What reaลฟons can you giue againลฟt the bodily preลฟence of Chriลฟt in the Sacrament?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Firลฟt, were hee corporally and carnally preลฟent in the Sacrament, then his Body muลฟt of neceลฟลฟitie be in many ลฟeuerall places at one and the ลฟame inลฟtant, which is directly contrary to the nature of a true humane body, ลฟuch as Chriลฟt aลฟลฟumed,Iohn 11.15.21 retayned, and ลฟo ลฟhall doe for euer; euen a body inH โข b. 2.14. & 4.15. all things like vnto ours; ลฟinne onely excepted.

Secondly, this carnall preลฟence of Chriลฟt, deลฟtroyes the end for which this Sacrament was ordained of him,1 Cor. 11.24, 25, โข 6. Luke 22.19. which was to kรฉepe him, his death and paลฟลฟion in continuall remembrance among vs, vntill his comming againe. Now this is altogether vaine and nรฉedleลฟลฟe, if he be here in body preลฟent with vs; for helpes of remembrance are not of preลฟent, but things abลฟent onely.

Thirdly,Iohn 6.63. becauลฟe our Sauiour Chriลฟt in plaine termes, affirmes his corporall preลฟence and fleลฟhly eating of him, to be wholly vnprofitable, and to auaile vs nothing at all to ลฟaluation.
Fourthly, nothing is more certaine then that the Body of Chriลฟt is in Heauen,Epheลฟ. 1.20. and there muลฟt be till the day of Iudgement.

Fiftly, the faithfull in the Sacraments of the Old Teลฟtament, did eate the ลฟame ลฟpirituall meate,1 Cor. 10.1, 2.3, 4. and drinke the ลฟame ลฟpirituall drinke, that we doe in the Sacrament of the New: But they could not eate the body of Chriลฟt, nor drinke his Bloud, otherwiลฟe then
by faith, for they were not then in the world, ergo, &c.

p.hi: You doe not hold then, that by vertue of theลฟe words (For this is my Body, &c.) pronounced by a Prieลฟt ouer the Bread and Wine, the ลฟubลฟtance of the Bread is turned into the very Body of Chriลฟt, and the ลฟubลฟtance of Wine into his very Bloud, ลฟo as nothing remaines of either but the bare formes, ลฟhewes, likeneลฟลฟes or apparances of them onely?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
By no meanes, but contrariwiลฟe, I condemne and reiect it for a moลฟt groลฟลฟe and palpable abลฟurditie, contrary to Scripture, to reaลฟon, to the truth of Chriลฟts humane Body, to diuerลฟe Articles of our faith; to the nature, end, and vลฟe of a Sacrament; to the iudgement of our ลฟenลฟes, of ancient Fathers, of whole Churches and holy Martyrs, who haue ลฟealed the contrary by their deareลฟt bloud; yea it is an inuention ลฟo infinitely monลฟtrous, as that the very Patrons and defenders of it, are contrary one to another about it, ลฟighting like the Midianites each againลฟt his fellow, and can no better agrรฉe together, then the falลฟe
witneลฟลฟes ลฟuborned againลฟt our Sauiour Chriลฟt.

p.hi: What then will you make to be the meaning of thoลฟe words, when hee affirmes of the Bread that it is his Body, and of the Cup, that it is his Bloud?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
They are not to be vnderลฟtood, neither ลฟubลฟtantially, as if the Bread ลฟhould be the very Body, or the Wine the very Bloud of Chriลฟt; neither may they bee vnderลฟtood conลฟubลฟtantially, as if the Body of Chriลฟt were included in the Bread, and his Bloud in the Wine; but they are figuratiue ลฟpรฉeches, in which the names of the things ลฟignified are attributed to the ลฟignes thereof: And the meaning of them is in effect thus much, as if our Sauiour had ลฟaid; Thoลฟe viลฟible Elements of Bread and Wine, doe ลฟignifie and repreลฟent vnto you, my Body crucified, and my Bloud ลฟhed, for remiลฟลฟion of your ลฟinnes; and are pleadges, ลฟcales and aลฟลฟurances vnto you, that as verily as you receiue theลฟe creatures of Bread and Wine, into your bodies, to their comfo โข t and nouriลฟhment:
So you are as certainely made partakers of my very Body and Bloud ลฟpiritually by faith, to the eternall comfort and ลฟaluation of your ลฟoules.

p.hi: How doe you prooue, that this expoลฟition which you haue giuen, is the true and genuine meaning of theลฟe words?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Becauลฟe the1 Cor. 10.16. It is the vลฟuall Language of the Scripture ลฟpeaking of Sacraments, to call the ลฟigne by the name of the thing ลฟignified; as Gen. 17.10, 11. Rom 4.11. Exod. 12 11.13.27. 1 Cor. 10.4. Tit. 3.5. 1 Cor. 11.25. Scripture it ลฟelfe, and ancientTertul. Lib. 4. cont. Marc. Aug. cont. Adimant. Cap. 12. and Epiลฟt. 23. Fathers ลฟo expound them. Secondly, this Expoลฟition doth well conลฟent with theLuke 22.19. words of Inลฟtitution, with theConcerning the truth of Chriลฟt his humane nature, his Aลฟcenลฟion, ลฟeลฟลฟion at the right hand of God, &c. Articles of our Faith, and theWhich euer neceลฟลฟarily requires an outward viลฟible ลฟigne, and an inward inuiลฟible thing ลฟignified thereby; both which, by this Expoลฟition, are ratified and confirmed to the Euchariลฟt. nature of Sacraments.

p.hi: What are the actions to be performed by the Miniลฟter in the adminiลฟtration of this Sacrament?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p:
Mat. 26.26, 27. Luke 22.17, 18.19, 20.Firลฟt, to take the Bread and Wine into his hands. Secondly, to bleลฟลฟe and conลฟecrate them. Thirdly,
to breake the one,1 Cor. 11.23, 2 โข 25. and powre forth the other. Fourthly, to giue them both into the hands of the Communicants.

p.hi: Is the action of breaking the Bread an indifferent rite, ลฟo as it may be admitted or omitted, vลฟed or not vลฟed at the pleaลฟure of the Miniลฟter?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No; but it is a neceลฟลฟary Ceremonie not to bee neglected or paลฟลฟed ouer.

p.hi: Why?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Becauลฟe Chriลฟt himลฟelfe the author and ordayner of this Sacrament,Mat. 26.26. Marke 14.22. whoลฟe example we muลฟtMat. 11.28.29 follow, gaue not the Bread whole, but firลฟt brake it, and then gaue it to his Diลฟciples.
Secondly,Luke 22.19. he expreลฟลฟely commands the breaking of it.

Thirdly, the1 Cor. 10.16. Apoลฟtles and Paลฟtors of the Church,As by the writings of the Fathers, and Eccleลฟiaลฟticall Hiลฟtories doth appeare. for many hundred yรฉers after them, did euer obลฟerue this Ceremonie.

Fourthly, the whole ลฟeruice of celebrating the Lords Supper, hath his denomination from this action,Acts 2.42.46. & 20.7. and is often in the Scripture called breaking of Bread, which certainely ลฟhould not
haue bรฉene, were it not a neceลฟลฟary rite that might not be omitted.

Fiftly, it is a liuely and moลฟt effectuall repreลฟentation of the breaking of the Body of Chriลฟt,1 Cor. 11.24. Gal. 3.13. Heb. 9, 26, &c. and of the bitter death and infinite torments he endured for our ลฟinnes; on which, the whole hope and comfort of our ลฟoules depends, and for memoriall and repreลฟentation whereof, this Sacrament was ordained.

p.hi: What are the actions to bee performed by the Communicants or Receiuers?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Mat. 26.26, 27. 1 Cor. 11.23, 24, 25.Firลฟt, to take the Bread and the Wine into their hands. Secondly, to eate the one, and drinke the other, to the nouriลฟhment of their bodies.

p.hi: Is the Wine then to be adminiลฟtred to the People, and they to drinke of the ลฟame, as well as to receiue and eate the Bread?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
Yes doubtleลฟลฟe; for Chriลฟt in the inลฟtitution of this Sacrament,Mat. 26, 27. Luke 22.17. deliuered the Cup as well as the Bread, to all his Diลฟciples, in that action, holding the place, not of Paลฟtors, but of the people: and commanded them all
to drinke the ลฟame.
Secondly, the Apoลฟtle Paul, not by any priuate motion,1 Cor. 11.28. but guided by the Spirit of God, enioynes all Chriลฟtians to communicate in both kindes.

Thirdly, it is a part of Chriลฟts Will and Teลฟtament,Luke 22.20. 1 Cor. 11.25. ratified by his death and bloud-ลฟhed, which by no meanes oughtGal. 3.15. Heb. 9.16, 17. to be violated, that the people ลฟhould partake of the Wine as well as of the B โข ead.

Fourthly, becauลฟe els the people ลฟhould haue but an halfe and inลฟufficient,See Iohn 6.54.55, 66. not a full and perfect nouriลฟhment of their ลฟoules, by Ieลฟus Chriลฟt, reลฟembled and ลฟealed to them in this Sacrament; for our perfect and compleate bodily nouriลฟhment, conลฟiลฟts not in meate onely, but in meate and drinke both together.

Fiftly, the1 Cor. 10.21. & 11.26, 27.29. & 12, 13. Primitiue Church adminiลฟtred the Communion vnder both kindes to the people; and it hath bรฉene the conลฟtant cuลฟtome of the Chriลฟtian Churches ลฟo to doe, for the ลฟpace of more then a thouลฟand yรฉeres together, after the times of the Apoลฟtles.

Sixtly,1 Cor. 10.4. the Iลฟraelites dranke of the
Rocke in the Wilderneลฟลฟe, which in effect, was the ลฟame Sacrament with ours.

Seuenthly, the Bloud of Chriลฟt and Merit thereof, appertaines no leลฟลฟe to the people,Acts 2 โข .28. 1 Pet. 1.18.19. Mat. 20.26. being belรฉeuers, then to the Paลฟtors and Miniลฟters; and therefore the ลฟigne and ลฟeale thereof, which is the Cup or Wine, may be no more denyed vnto the one then to the other.

p.hi: What is it to eate the Fleลฟh or Body of Chriลฟt, and to drinke his Bloud?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Not to receiue and fรฉede vpon his Body and BloudIohn 6.62, 93. carnally, with the mouth of the body, but ลฟpiritually with the mouth of the ลฟoule, which is, aliuely faith; that is to ลฟay, toIohn 6.35.47.50, 51, &c. belรฉeue, and bee perลฟwaded, that the Body of Chriลฟt was crucified, and his Bloud ลฟhed, for a full remiลฟลฟion of all our ลฟinnes; and not onely ลฟo, but (afterEpheลฟ. 5.32. an incomprehenลฟible manner) to be1 Cor. 10.16, 17. vnited vnto Chriลฟt, as the members of the body vnto the head, and ลฟo to be made partakers of hisIoh. 6.55, 56. righteouลฟneลฟลฟe, life, glory, and whatลฟoeuer his benefits, as truly and verily as we are of the outward Elements of Bread and Wine.

p.hi: Then no wicked impenitent, vngodly perลฟon, &c. vnbeleeuer, hypocrite &c. though they be preลฟent at this Sacrament, doth eate the fleลฟh, or drinke the Bloud of Chriลฟt, doth he?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No. It is not poลฟลฟible they ลฟhould.

p.hi: What receiue they then in this Sacrament?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Onely the outward Symboles or Elements, and nothing elลฟe;Iohn 6.54, 55, 56. they get the ลฟhell, but not the Kernell, they eate the Bread of the Lord, but not that Bread which is the Lord.

p.hi: What are the ends of the Lords Supper?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Firลฟt,Luke 22.19, 20 1 Cor. 11.20.25. Iohn 6.56. to ลฟignifie and aลฟลฟure our continuance, preลฟeruation and nouriลฟhment in the couenant of grace, the familie and Church of God, into which, by baptiลฟme wee had entrance and admiลฟลฟion.
Secondly,1 Cor. 10.16. to ลฟeale and confirme more and more our communion with Chriลฟt, and all his benefits.

Thirdly,1 Cor. 10.17. & 12, 13. to declare and admoniลฟh vs of that nรฉere fellowลฟhip and communion, which is betwรฉene all faithfull
receiuers of this Sacrament; who are all ioynt members of the ลฟame body myลฟticall in Chriลฟt, bone of each others bone, and fleลฟh of each others fleลฟh.
Rom. 4.11. 1 Cor. 10.16 & 11.24, 25, 26.Fourthly, to ลฟtrengthen and increaลฟe our faith and all other ลฟauing graces.
Luke 22.19.Fiftly, to celebrate and preลฟerue the memory of our Sauiours death and paลฟลฟion, and of the ineลฟtimable benefits wee reape thereby, vntill his glorious appearing to iudge the world.

p.hi: Whom are the Paลฟtors or Miniลฟters of the Church to admit to this Sacrament?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
All and onely ลฟuch as haue byExod. 12.43, 44, &c. Baptiลฟme bรฉene admitted into the Church, and continue the profeลฟลฟed members thereof, and are for yรฉeres,1 Cor. 11.24.29. vnderลฟtanding and knowledge of the Principles of Chriลฟtian Religion, and particularly, of the Doctrine of the Sacraments, able to1 Cor. 11.28 examine and prepare themลฟelues for the worthy receiuing of it; and withall, doe by their Chriลฟtian andMat. 7.6. vnblamable conuerลฟation, giue probable teลฟtimonies,
that they are indued with a true ลฟauing faith in Ieลฟus Chriลฟt, and vnfained repentance for their ลฟinnes.

p.hi: Doth it not therefore ลฟtand euery Miniลฟter vpon, to examine ลฟuch as he admits vnto it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Certainely it doth; for it is his duty, toIer. 15.19. ลฟeparate the pretious from the vile, and to beware that he doe not proลฟtitute the holy things of the Lord, toMat. 7.6. Dogges and Swine.

Secondly, it is his duty at all times to be carefull of acquainting himลฟelfe with the ลฟtate of his Flocke;Pro. 27.23. Acts 20.28. and therefore much more then, when hee is to receiue them to this holy Table.
Thirdly,2 Chron. 35.6. & 30.17. he is to helpe the people in their preparation, that they may bee worthy receiuers.

Fourthly, whomลฟoeuer he admits vnto it, being vnworthy and vnprepared,1 Tim. 5.22. hee makes himลฟelfe acceลฟลฟory to their ลฟinnes, and culpable of prophaning the ลฟacred pleadges of the Lords Body and Bloud.

p.hi: Then it is the peoples duty alลฟo to bee willing and ready to ลฟubmit themลฟelue, to their Miniลฟters examination, is it not?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: It is ลฟo, for euery Chriลฟtian is bound to bee alwayes ready to giue an anลฟwer to any man that ลฟhall aske him a reaลฟon of the hope that is in him:1 Pet. 3.15. much more therefore ought he to ลฟhew this readineลฟลฟe to his lawfull Paลฟtor, who, by God, is placed ouer him.

Secondly, God chargeth euery man to bee obedient to h โข s Paลฟtor, and with all meekeneลฟลฟe and humbleneลฟลฟe of minde,Deut. 17.11.12 1 Theลฟ. 5.12. Heb. 13.17. to ลฟubmit themลฟelues vnto him, in all things which concerne the worลฟhip of God, and good of their owne ลฟoules; of which nature this is one.

Thirdly, God requires of all ลฟuch as are to bee baptized,Mat. 3.6. Marke 1.5. Acts 8.37. 1 Pet. 3.21. being men of yรฉeres, that firลฟt they giue euidence of their knowledge, faith and repentance, to the Miniลฟter that baptizes them: and therefore it is not to bee imagined that he requires any leลฟลฟe of thoลฟe that are to partake of the Lords Supper.

p.hi: Who may not be admitted to this Sacrament, but muลฟt be barred from it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
AllExod. 12.43, 44. 2 Cor. 6.14, 15, 16. Epheลฟ. 2.11, 12, &c. Infidels, all perลฟonsExod 12.43, 4 โข 48. Diลฟciples, ลฟo Acts 20.7. vnbaptized, allTheลฟe cannot eate, drink, remember Chriลฟts death, &c. Mat. 26.26. departed this life, allNone of theลฟe are able to examine themลฟelues, diลฟcerne the Lo โข ds Body, commemorate his death, &c. 1 Cor. 11.24.25.26.27.28.29. Infants, all Ignorants that know
not the fundamentall points of Religion; all Idiots, Fooles, furious, franticke and mad men; allP โข al. 50.16, 17. Eลฟay 1.11. & 66.3. 1 Cor. 10.21.22. ลฟcandalous wicked impenitent liuers, and whoลฟoeuer are by the Gouernours of the Church worthilyMat. 18.17. 1 Cor. 5.5. 1 Tim. 1.20. excommunicated.

p.hi: What are we to doe that wee may be worthy receiuers of this Sacrament?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That we may worthily partake of it, to our comfort and edification, there bee ลฟome duties to be practiลฟed of vs, before we reลฟort to it; ลฟome in the time of our receiuing, ลฟome after wee haue receiued.

p.hi: What are the duties to be practiลฟed before our reลฟorting to it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Wee muลฟt diligently prepare and examine our ลฟelues.

p.hi: Why are we ลฟo to doe?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Firลฟt, becauลฟe in the Old Teลฟtament, all were to prepare and ลฟanctifie themลฟelues, before they might either offer1 Sam. 16.5. ลฟacrifice, or celebrate the2 Chron. 35.6. Paลฟลฟeouer.
Secondly, becauลฟe we are bound to prepare our ลฟelues before other the ลฟeruices of God, asEccleลฟ. 5.2. Prayer,Eccleลฟ. 5.1. Luke 8.18. hearing his Word.
Thirdly, becauลฟe whoลฟoeuer receiues vnworthily,1 Cor. 11.27.39. is guilty of the Body and Bloud of Chriลฟt, and eates and drinkes his owne damnation.

p.hi: What things muลฟt wee examine our ลฟelues of?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: 1 Cor. 10.15, 16.Firลฟt, whether (at the leaลฟt in ลฟome competent meaลฟure) wee know the grounds of Religion, and in particular, the Doctrine of the Sacraments.

2 Cor 13.5. Heb. 11.6.28.Secondly, whether we bee endued with a true iuลฟtifying, ลฟauing faith in Ieลฟus Chriลฟt, applying all his merits to our owne ลฟoules, and reลฟting vpon them, as appertayning to our ลฟelues in particular, as well as to any other.

Thirdly, whether we doe1 Kings. 8.48. ลฟeriouลฟly and vnfainedly,1 Cor. 5.8. & 1 โข .28, 29.31. repent vs of our ลฟinnes, heartily2 Cor. 7, 8, 9, 10.11. ลฟorrowing and grieuing for them, and that eลฟpecially in this reลฟpect, becauลฟe thereby wee haue offended ลฟo louing and gracious aPลฟal 51.4. father; t โข ulyPลฟal. 119.104 128. hating and deteลฟting
them, and fullyPลฟal. 119 57.106. reลฟoluing toPลฟal. 34.14. Eลฟay 1. โข 6. abandon themEzek. 18.21. all, for2 Pet. 2.21.22 euer; and to leade a newMat. 3.8. life, in anIer. 11.4. vniuerลฟall andPลฟal. 119.33.44.112. conลฟtant obedience to allExod. 19.8. Gods Commandements.

Fourthly, whether we be inMarke 11.25 loue and charity with all men, euen ourMat. 5.44, 45. Enemies; frรฉely and heartilyMat. 6.12.14, 15. forgiuing ลฟuch as haue wronged or iniured vs, in word or dรฉede; euen as wee deลฟire that God, for Chriลฟts ลฟake, ลฟhould forgiue vs.
Therefore the ancient Chriลฟtians were wont by a mutuall kiลฟลฟe, to teลฟtifie their vnfained loue each to other, before their receiuing of the Lords Supper.

p.hi: What if a man vpon examination find theลฟe graces in him, but in a very weake meaลฟure, and with great and manifold infirmities and imperfections, is he therefore to abลฟtaine?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p:
No, by no meanes, if ลฟo bee hee perceiue them in himลฟelfe, though in neuer ลฟo2 Chron. 30.17, 18, 19, 20. weake a meaลฟure, ลฟo they be in truth and ลฟinceritie; and pleaลฟe not himลฟelfe in his wants, but bee vnfainedly i grieued for them,Marke 9.24. i ลฟtriues againลฟt
them, and earneลฟtlyMat. 5, 6. deลฟires to grow in grace; he ought to come whoลฟoeuer hee be. Yea, the imperfections and wants of our faith, repentance, and other ลฟauing graces, ลฟhould bee ลฟo farre from kรฉeping vs away, or diลฟcouraging vs from it, as that they ought rather to bee ลฟharpeRom. 4.11. ลฟpurres and motiues, to prouoke vs to a more frequent and diligent vลฟe of the ลฟame, that thereby we may get them ลฟtrengthened, confirmed and encreaลฟed; this Sacrament being the meanes appointed of God, for that very end and purpoลฟe.

p.hi: What other duties are there to bee performed of vs, before our comming to this Sacrament?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Mat. 5.6.Wee are to prouoke our ลฟelues to an ardent and longing deลฟire after it.
Secondly, we muลฟt earneลฟtly pray vnto God,Acts 2.42. that hee will bee pleaลฟed of his gracious goodneลฟลฟe, to vouchลฟafe his bleลฟลฟing vpon our partaking of the ลฟame.

p.hi: Is it neceลฟลฟary to our preparation that we come faลฟting to it?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Noe certainely; fitteลฟt it is for ลฟuch as are able without preiudice of their health to forbeare meate ลฟo long, to receiue it faลฟting, that in honour of ลฟo great a Sacrament the Lords body may firลฟt enter into their mouthes, before any other earthly meates: but for ลฟuch as are not, they may without ลฟcruple of conลฟcience, or offence to God, take ลฟome ลฟmall refreลฟhing before they come; for God no whereEลฟay. 8. โข 0. commands the contrary, neither doth hisRom. 14.17. Kingdome ลฟtand in meate and drinke. Alลฟo our Sauiour Chriลฟt adminiลฟtred it to his Apoลฟtles after SupperLuke 22.20., and moreouer (to make it without controuerลฟie) the Scripture expreลฟลฟely1 Cor. 11.34 warrants and approoues of eating, in caลฟe one be hungry, before he communicate.

p.hi: What duties are wee to performe during the time while the Sacrament is adminiลฟtring?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: We muลฟt be carefull to behaue our ลฟelues with all ลฟeemely religiousLeuit. 19.30. Pลฟal. 2.11. reuerence, duely conลฟidering that the Lord in a moลฟt ลฟpeciall manner is here preลฟentMatth. 18.20. Pลฟal. 26.8. among vs.

Secondly, wee muลฟt in our ลฟoules let the incenลฟe of our vnfeined and heartieลฟtMat. 26.26.30 & 103.1.2. &c. thankลฟgiuing aลฟcend vp vnto the Throne of God, for his vnลฟpeakeableIohn 3.16. 1 Ioh. 4.9.10.11 loue towards vs, in giuing his only begotten Sonne to ลฟuch a curลฟed death, and infinite torments for vs; which in this Sacrament as it were in a Table, moลฟtGal. 3.1. liuely and graphically are purtraied forth vnto vs.

Thirdly wee muลฟt with all heedfull regard obลฟerue the ลฟignes of bread and wine, with all the Sacramentall rites, ceremonies, and actions, both on the Miniลฟters and Receiuers part performed about them; ลฟeriouลฟly weighing,1 Cor. 11.24.25 Exo. 12.26. & 24.8. and pondering in our mindes, the ลฟeuerall things ลฟignified, ลฟealed, and repreลฟented vnto vs thereby.

p.hi: When we ลฟet two ลฟignes vpon the Table, both Bread and Wine, what are we then to thinke vpon?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That Ieลฟus Chriลฟt is both Bread and Water of life vnto vs, that is to ลฟay, our perfect and all-ลฟufficient Redeemer,Heb. 7.25. Ioh. โข .35.54.55 Heb. 10.14. in whom, and in whom alone is aboundantly to be found whatลฟoever is requiลฟite to our euerlaลฟting ลฟaluation.

p.hi: When we behold the Miniลฟter by rehearลฟall of the inลฟtitution, prayers, &c. to conลฟecrate and ลฟet apart the Bread and VVine to this ลฟacred vลฟe, what meditation are we then to haue?

sp.speaker: B.

p.hi: VVhen we ลฟee the Bread broken, and VVine powred forth, what are wee then to call to mind?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: That our bleลฟลฟed Sauiour Ieลฟus Chriลฟt was as it were1 Cor. 11.24. Eลฟa. 53.3.5. &c. broken with inexpreลฟลฟeable tortures, and his bloudIoh. 19.34. Luk. 22.20. 1 Iohn 1.7. moลฟt cruelly ลฟhed, to make ลฟatiลฟfaction to the iuลฟtice of God for our ลฟins, for which otherwiลฟe we ลฟhould both in body and ลฟoule haue for euerDeut 27.26. p.hi: VVhat muลฟt the Miniลฟters giuing the Bread thus broken, and the VVine ลฟo powred forth, ลฟuggeลฟt vnto vs?

sp.speaker: B.

That the body of Chriลฟt was ลฟo broken, and his bloud ลฟhed for vs and our ลฟaluation in particularGal. 2.20. as well as for any other: and that as the Miniลฟter
doeth viลฟibly and corporally giue theลฟe ลฟignes of Bread and Wine vnto vs, which nouriลฟh our bodies: So verily doth God now inuiลฟibly, and in a ลฟpirituall manner, offer and exhibite the veryIohn 6.32.50 51, 52. &c. 1 Cor. 10.16, 17 fleลฟh & bloud of Chriลฟt vnto our ลฟoules, to be the foode and nouriลฟhment thereof vnto eternall life.

p.hi: What are we to doe when we take and receiue the Bread and Wine into our hands from the Miniลฟter?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Then we muลฟt as it were awaken, and rouze vp our ลฟoules to reach forth the hand of faith, and thereby to take and apply vnto our ลฟelues Ieลฟus Chriลฟt,Iohn 1.12. and 6.35 40.47.48. &c. with all his ลฟauing merits.

p.hi: VVhat is our eating of the Bread and drinking of the VVine, to cauลฟe vs to meditate on?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Euen vpon that moลฟt nรฉere and ลฟtreight vnion thereby ลฟignified, that is betwรฉene Chriลฟt Ieลฟus, our ลฟelues, and euery true belรฉeuer; that hee is no leลฟลฟe nรฉerely and ลฟtraightly ioyned to vs, and we to him, as alลฟo to one another, then the Bread and Wine which we receiue,1 Cor. 10.16.17 and 12.12, 13. eate and drinke, are to our bodies.

p.hi: What duties are wee to performe after wee haue receiued this Sacrament?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: We ought euery one, according to our abilitie, chรฉerefully and willingly to conลฟecrate ลฟome portion of that which God hath bleลฟลฟed vs with,1 Cor. 16.2. Nehem. 8.10. Heb 13.16. towards the reliefe of our poore and niedy Brethren among vs.

p.hi: Is the receiuing of this Sacrament, a thing arbitrary or indifferent, ลฟo as wee may communicate or not, at our owne pleaลฟures?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: No; but all ลฟuch as are baptized, being of yรฉeres and fitneลฟลฟe to examine and prepare themลฟelues,Mar. 26.26.27. 1 Cor. 11.24.25 and not hauing any iuลฟt impediment, are bound to partake of it.

p.hi: How may that appeare?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Firลฟt, becauลฟe God hath expreลฟลฟely inioyned and commanded it.Luk. 22.19.20. 2. Chron. 30.8. confer with the verลฟes preced.
Secondly, it is a part of his publike diuine worลฟhip.
Thirdly, the neglect of it, is a very heynous and grieuous ลฟinne,Numb. 9.13. Gen. 17.19. Ex. 4.24.25.26. greatly prouoking the wrath of God againลฟt ลฟuch as are guilty of it.

Fourthly, it is one of the meanes appointed of God, to preลฟerue, cheriลฟh
and increaลฟe in vs our faith, and other ลฟpirituall graces.Rom. 4.11. 1 Cor. 10.16. & 11.24.25.26.

Fiftly, this Sacrament is one of the badges and cogniลฟances, and as it were, the armes of our Lord and Maลฟter Ieลฟus Chriลฟt; by receiuing whereof, his pleaลฟure is, that wee ลฟhould make publike profeลฟลฟion of being his Diลฟciples and Seruants,Exo. 12.43, 44. Gen. 17.11, &c. Acts 2.41.42. Acts 20.7. and bee knowne and diลฟtinguiลฟhed from all other Sects and profeลฟลฟions in the world.

p.hi: How oft are wee to celebrate and partake of the Lords Supper?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: We may not content our ลฟelues to come to it at Eaลฟter, or once, or twice in the yรฉere, as if that were ลฟufficient; but we muลฟt receiue it as often as fit opportunitie is offered, and as with conueniencie we may.

p.hi: VVhy are wee to receiue it often?

sp.speaker: B.
sp.p: Firลฟt, becauลฟe our Sauiour Chriลฟt commands the frequent vลฟe of it.1 Cor. 11.25.
Acts 2.41.42. and 20.7. 1 Cor. 11.26.Secondly, the Apoลฟtles did often adminiลฟter it.

Thirdly, it was the conลฟtant practice of the Chriลฟtian Churches long
after the Apoลฟtles time, to communicate often; of ลฟome, as often as they met together, to heare the Word of God; of ลฟome, euery Lords day; of ลฟome euery day in the weeke; of all, many times in the yeere.

Fourthly, becauลฟe our Sauiour Chriลฟt departing this world, inioyned vs to celebrate this Sacrament,Luk. 22.19. 1 Cor. 11.24.29 in remembrance, and in teลฟtimonie of our vnfayned thankfulneลฟลฟe for his bitter death and paลฟลฟion, which hee endured for our ลฟinnes. It muลฟt nรฉedes bee therefore horrible ingratitude not to doe it often.

Fiftly, becauลฟe it is a meanes ordayned of God for the preลฟeruing,Rom. 4.11. 1 Cor. 10.16. nouriลฟhing and increaลฟing of the ลฟpirituall life of our ลฟoules, and the ลฟanctifying graces of the holy Ghoลฟt, euen as hee hath ordained his creatures for preลฟeruation and nouriลฟhment of our corporall life: As therefore wee doe often feede vpon theลฟe, ลฟo ought wee in like manner often to rec โข iue the other.

Sixtly, to neglect receiuing of it, when it is adminiลฟtred in that congregation, whereof we are members, vnleลฟลฟe
by ลฟickneลฟลฟe or ลฟome other neceลฟลฟary impediment we be hindered, is a fearefull contempt of Gods ลฟacred ordinances and ลฟeales of grace, as alลฟo of thoลฟe inualuable benefits which in the ลฟame are proffered and confirmed vnto vs;Gen. 17.14. Num. 9.13. 1 Cor. 10 16. and 11.24.25. which cannot be but a moลฟt hainous ลฟinne, and greatly incenลฟe the wrath of God againลฟt vs.

p.hi: I will propound but one queลฟtion more vnto you concerning this Sacrament, and ลฟo paลฟลฟe from it. Secondly, becauลฟe the ลฟinne and penalty of vnworthy receiuing, is limited and appropriated by God,1 Cor. 11.29. only to the perลฟons ลฟelfe vnworthily communicating.

Thirdly, becauลฟe theEลฟa. 1, 2, 3, &c. Iere. 6.13. &c. and 8.10. &c. and 5.1. Hoลฟ. 4.1, 2. read & obลฟerue the other Prophets alลฟo. Prophets, theLuk. 24.53. Act. 2.46. & 3.1 Apoลฟtles, yea, our moลฟt innocent and holyLuk. 4.16. and 19.47. & 22.53. Iohn 18.20. Sauiour himลฟelfe, for whom it was impoลฟลฟible to erre or ลฟin liuing in moลฟt prophane, godleลฟลฟe and irreligious times, when all wickedneลฟลฟe and impietie reigned and abounded among all ลฟorts of men: yet none of them did ลฟeparate from, or forลฟake the aลฟลฟemblies of the people, but ioyned euen with the vngodly themลฟelues in the publike exerciลฟes of Religion, and the commanded duties of Gods worลฟhip.
